title: 103_hr1727
content: The Act may be cited as the "Arson Prevention Act of 1994". Congress finds that arson is a serious problem in the United States, responsible for 25% of all fires, leading to 700 deaths annually, and causing $2 billion in property losses. Arson is underreported due to lack of participation in reporting systems. There is a need for expanded training programs for arson investigators. Improved training programs for volunteer firefighters are necessary to detect and preserve evidence of arson crimes. Only a third of suspicious fires are confirmed as arson, highlighting the need for better arson investigator training to identify and prosecute arson offenses effectively. SEC. 25. ARSON PREVENTION GRANTS are added to the Federal Fire Prevention and Control Act of 1974 to provide funding for arson prevention efforts. The Office of Fire Prevention and Arson Control defines arson as incendiary and suspicious fires. The Administrator will grant awards to States for arson research, prevention, and control programs. Grants will be awarded based on competitive merit to improve training for arson investigators. The Office of Fire Prevention and Arson Control grants awards to States for arson research, prevention, and control programs. This includes resources for arson task forces, combating fraud as a motive for arson, managing arson squads with training courses and public education materials. The Office of Fire Prevention and Arson Control grants awards to States for arson research, prevention, and control programs. This includes resources for combating civil unrest, juvenile arson, drug-related arson, domestic violence-related arson, and arson in rural areas. The Office of Fire Prevention and Arson Control grants awards to States for arson research, prevention, and control programs, including combating civil unrest, juvenile arson, drug-related arson, domestic violence-related arson, and arson in rural areas. Firefighters' capability to identify and prevent arson-initiated fires in rural areas and public forests is improved through expanded training programs, including courses at State fire academies and innovative courses delivered through teleconferencing and satellite TV programs. The Administrator assists grant applicants in structuring their applications to ensure grants are awarded for each goal described in the program. States must meet qualification criteria to receive grants. The State or consortium must provide assurances to the Administrator for the grant, including obtaining 25% of program costs from non-Federal sources, maintaining prior spending levels for arson programs, limiting administrative costs to 10%, and ensuring local jurisdictions provide arson data. Grants may be extended based on availability of appropriations. The Administrator will provide technical assistance to States for programs funded by grants under this section. They will also consult and cooperate with other Federal agencies to enhance program effectiveness and avoid duplication of effort. A report identifying grants and grantees must be submitted to Congress within 18 months of enactment. The Administrator will issue regulations for grant applications and directly administer the grant program. Recipients are encouraged to purchase American-made equipment with grant funds. The Administrator will issue regulations for grant applications and directly administer the grant program, encouraging recipients to purchase American-made equipment with grant funds. Recipients will receive a notice describing the statement made by Congress when expending grant monies. SEC. 4 amends the Federal Fire Prevention and Control Act to emphasize the need for arson training for volunteer firefighters. SEC. 5 adds a new section requiring CPR training for firefighters to receive funds. SEC. 6 provides exceptions for federal employee housing. SEC. 6 amends the Federal Fire Prevention and Control Act to exempt federal employee housing from certain fire protection requirements. Section 17 of the Federal Fire Prevention and Control Act of 1974 is amended to authorize appropriations for various purposes including research on arson prevention, expansion of arson investigator training programs, and funding for carrying out specific sections of the Act for fiscal years 1995 and 1996. SEC. 8. SUNSET. No funds authorized after fiscal year 1996 for programs in this Act or its amendments.
